It makes you realize that the ending doesn't ruin the story, it enhances the value of the second playthrough. Megan was being abused by her church's priest in the 70s, and the tried so hard to tell her family, but none of them would give her the time of day. So she made up a figure to speak to that would allow her to vent. The witch trial sections of this game are a representation of a process in Anthony's mind. He's thinking of all the ways that his family members were guilty of neglecting Megan, and how their 'demons' led Megan to act out and destroy the house, killing the family. At the same time, Andrew is sorting through his own grief of being unable to save his family. The first playthrough of this game makes you hate it, but playing again lets you piece it together accurately and experience the reality of what is happening in the story.

Little Hope is however markedly improved from Man of Medan, which was a campy train-wreck of a script.
